awd_titl_txt: Is Wireless Channel Dependable for Security Provisioning?
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent progress in wireless system and network security exploits wireless channel characteristics, also known as link signatures, to offer enhanced and sometimes the only available security solutions for ubiquitous wireless applications; two prominent examples are link-signature based secret key generation and physical layer authentication. However, it is found that the current link-signature study makes wrong assumptions about the adversary's inference capability, which will expose the legitimate systems to severe threats with little awareness.

Objective:                    
The objective of this project is to seek a fundamental understanding of the limits in adversarial inference of wireless channel characteristics, and develop stronger link-signature based security mechanisms for wireless communications. Various analytical channel correlation models involving important physical propagation factors in typical wireless environments will be investigated, and effective inference algorithms and practical designs will be explored from the adversary's position, to determine the vulnerability of existing wireless security mechanisms. Then, two approaches will be considered to further strengthen the current wireless security solutions: one is to exploit multiple-antenna and cooperative communication techniques to disrupt the adversarial inference process, and the other is to integrate cryptographic techniques into link-signature constructions to achieve improved and guaranteed protection.

Intellectual merit:        
The intellectual merit is correction of a wide-spread misconception about the link-signature security, and establishment of a proven scientific foundation facilitating the development of new wireless security mechanisms. 

Broader impacts:         
The broader impacts are significantly improvement in the security of current and emerging wireless devices and systems, cross-disciplinary education, and well-rounded training of future IT workforce.

por.por_cntn:
Wireless security is becoming increasingly important as wireless devices are pervasive and widely adopted in critical cyber-physical applications. On the other hand, unique features in the wireless medium, such as multipath channel characteristics, may be exploited for security provisioning. The success and further advancement of wireless security mechanisms depend crucially on a correct understanding of the underlying physical layer details and limits. In this project, we seek to gain a deeper understanding of the potentials and limitations of wireless-medium based security mechanisms, and endeavor to effectively exploit unique features at the wireless medium, together with advanced signal processing and cryptographic techniques, to develop strong security mechanisms for wireless communications.

Through this project, the following major research outcomes have been achieved towards our goal. Firstly, we challenge the commonly held assumption that half a wavelength separation is sufficient for channel decorrelation and security assurance of wireless physical layer security mechanisms. Through extensive modeling study, high channel correlation scenarios together with the underlying physical-layer settings are identified. Then a corresponding correlation attack is proposed, and security guard zones for existing wireless security mechanisms are redefined. Experimental results based on Universal Software Radio Peripheral (USRP) platforms and GNU Radio are conducted to further support the analysis. Link signature based security mechanisms have exhibited a great potential to advance wireless security. Our study can facilitate their further advancement with a more solid scientific foundation. Secondly, we explore a new concept, ally friendly jamming, that can disable unauthorized wireless communication and at the same time allow authorized devices to maintain wireless connectivity. We develop new techniques to generate ally jamming signals, to identify and synchronize with multiple ally jammers. We have also implemented a prototype for ally friendly jamming and performed extensive analysis and experimental evaluation to validate. Our ally friendly jamming techniques are expected to find wide applications in critical missions such as battlefield operations, anti-terrorism activities, and critical infrastructure protection. Thirdly , we propose a unified framework to study the connectivity of wireless networks under a general type of interference, including jamming, primary signaling in cognitive radio, and wireless shadowing as special cases. We determine a 3-d connectivity region, defined with respect to the set of key system parameters: the density of users, the density of Interferers and the interference range. Our unified framework can facilitate the study of security features for all relevant applications. Finally, in response to the growing intelligence and capability of the attackers, we undertake the game-theoretic approach to analyze the competing process  between the attacker and defender, which facilitates the development of optimal defending strategies. When the system information is not readily available, we further employ reinforcement learning techniques to gradually learn the optimal strategies in practice.

This project has led to the publication of 12 journal papers, 1 book, and 16 conference papers on premium venues of IEEE, with two of them receiving best paper awards. It has also contributed several software packages to the community on wireless security. This project has contributed to education through its impact on graduate course content in wireless communications and network security, through research seminars and invited talks (with one key-note speech at 2014 IEEE Conference on Communications and Network Security), and through participation in annual Engineering Open House, Senior Design Day, and Undergraduate Research Symposium at NCSU. This project has partially supported 2 postdoc researchers and 5 PhD students; 3 of them have graduated, with 2 working in academia (Hankuk University of Foreign Studies, South Korea and Lamar University) and 1 in industry (Samsung Research). Researchers and students who worked on this project developed research skills in theoretical analysis (in particular in game theory, percolation theory, and graph theory), algorithm design (in particular in security mechanism design), experimentation with GNU Radio and USRP platforms, as well as obtained experience with emerging communication technologies such as cognitive radio communications and cloud computing.
